MainHeading.Title: WRITTEN ANSWERS. - NEWBRIDGE OLD AGE PENSION ARREARS.

Speaker.hpid: AODH O CULACHAIN AODH O CULACHAIN
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Local Government and Public Health whether he is aware that Mrs. Alice Cash, Old Age Pensions Register No. 2242, of Roseberry Commons, Newbridge, Co. Kildare, was awarded a pension of 4/- per week as from October 1st, 1925, to be increased to 9/- per week when her total means would be reduced to 7/- per week, or £18 5s. per year; that Mrs. Cash did not receive any payment from October 1st, 1925, until January 23rd, 1926, when she received the full pension of 9s. and whether he will have inquiries made with a view to having the arrears of 4s. per week from the 1st October last paid forthwith.

MainHeading.Title: WRITTEN ANSWERS. - DIVISION OF CO. ROSCOMMON ESTATE.

Speaker.hpid: TOMAS O CONAILL TOMAS O CONAILL
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Lands and Agriculture whether it is the intention of the Land Commission to acquire and divide the estate known as the Hughes Estate, situated in the townland of Killer and Foughenagh, in the parish of Ballintubber, Co. Roscommon, and, if so, if he will state when it is hoped that the estate will be taken over and divided.

The Land Commission have had the untenanted lands in the townlands of Killer, Caraun and Fohenagh, on the estate of William Glover, inspected with a view to deciding as to their suitability for acquisition under the 1923 Act, and the matter will be dealt with as expeditiously as possible. MainHeading.Title: WRITTEN ANSWERS. - THE SHOOTING OF A PONY.

Speaker.hpid: RISTEARD O CONAILL RISTEARD O CONAILL
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance if he will state when a pay order will be issued in respect of an award of £20 made by the Compensation (Ireland) Commission in respect of a claim by James Ryan, Boherglass, Rathbane, Co. Limerick, for the shooting of a pony by British forces.

The award referred to by the Deputy cannot be discharged until certain income tax arrears due by the claimant have been adjusted with the Revenue Commissioners. If the matter is not adjusted very shortly, the entire award must be paid over to the Commissioners in part satisfaction of the arrears.

MainHeading.Title: WRITTEN ANSWERS. - TRACING A SURRENDERED GUN.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P.W. SHAW Mr. P.W. SHAW
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Defence if the double-barrelled breech-loading gun surrendered by Mr. Patrick Lestrange, Dysart, on September 14th, 1920, can now be traced; whether he is aware that the O/C Royal Arsenal, Woolwich, informed Mr. Lestrange that the gun is in Island Bridge Barracks, and if the gun cannot be traced whether the owner will receive compensation.

I was not aware that the O/C Royal Arsenal at Woolwich has stated definitely that Mr. Lestrange's gun is in Island Bridge Barracks. According to records, apparently, it should be there, but a careful search has, I regret to say, not lead to the finding of the weapon. As to compensation for its loss, Mr. Lestrange should communicate with the UnderSecretary of State, Home Office, Whitehall, London.

MainHeading.Title: WRITTEN ANSWERS. - AN OUTSTANDING LONGFORD ACCOUNT.

Mr. McGeeney's accounts against Army funds appear to have been settled. MainHeading.Title: WRITTEN ANSWERS. - SEQUEL TO ATHLONE EXPLOSION.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P.W. SHAW Mr. P.W. SHAW
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Defence if a decision has yet been come to in connection with the claim of Mrs. Tighe, Rath, Streete, Co. Westmeath, for compensation for the loss of her son, caused by an explosion in Athlone Military Barracks.
No claim appears to have been received from Mrs. Tighe for compensation in respect of the death of her son. If such a claim should be received it will be duly considered.

MainHeading.Title: WRITTEN ANSWERS. - THE BLACKWATER FISHERIES.

Speaker.hpid: TOMAS DE NOGLA TOMAS DE NOGLA
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries if it is proposed to hold an inquiry into the matter of the Blackwater Fisheries, No. 4 District, and, if so, whether the giving of evidence as to the construction of the King's Gap in the Lismore Weir, and the present method of working thereat, will be permitted; whether he has completed his inquiries regarding the election of a chairman for the Lismore district, and with what result.

Two applications for inquiries relative to the fisheries of the River Blackwater have been received. An inquiry will be held in due course into the question of the close season on the river. The other application is to hold an inquiry into the stock of salmon in the river, and the ground that it is injuriously affected by alleged illegalities at Lismore Weir, but the memorialists have, up to the present, failed to furnish further particulars for which they were asked. With regard to the question of alleged irregularities at the election of Conservators held at Fermoy, I would refer the Deputy to the reply given by me in this House on the 17th December last, to which I have nothing further to add.
